body:
> Can we separate the unrelated changes to another PR?
> 
> IMO, the lazy load should be implemented as following:
> 
> * Load the metadata, but keep the index in deep store
> * When segment gets queried, load index on demand
> 
> The current way of downloading all the segments, uncompress and load them at query time won't really work. @kishoreg wdyt?

I agree.

Another variant (if we want to escape the download part of latency) is to download it during state transition, but not load it in memory.  This variant can be useful in cases where an occasional query may cause some page churns but otherwise the working set returns to (say) most recent data.
Can we have a design doc on this before the PR review? Also what's the relationship between this and tiered storage https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/issues/5553? cc @npawar

Do you anticipate different auto-tuning customizations? In that case, is it better to have a config like:
`autoTuningStrategy: HighThroughput`, or `autoTuningStrategy: LowCost` or whatever.
thanks for creating the issue. I added a comment there

> Do you anticipate different auto-tuning customizations? In that case, is it better to have a config like:
> `autoTuningStrategy: HighThroughput`, or `autoTuningStrategy: LowCost` or whatever.

Yeah most likely will need different kinds of tuning. I'm not entirely sure we can encapsulate all those in a few keywords. For instance, indexing config is one subset. The other things we could tune is segment size / rows which could need another type of implementation. Of course, we can revisit this once we know more. For now, I thought the best approach is to leave this open.

> > Do you anticipate different auto-tuning customizations? In that case, is it better to have a config like:
> > `autoTuningStrategy: HighThroughput`, or `autoTuningStrategy: LowCost` or whatever.
> 
> Yeah most likely will need different kinds of tuning. I'm not entirely sure we can encapsulate all those in a few keywords. For instance, indexing config is one subset. The other things we could tune is segment size / rows which could need another type of implementation. Of course, we can revisit this once we know more. For now, I thought the best approach is to leave this open.

Do you anticipate exactly one auto-tuning customization to be used? I was just thinking of specifying a class name or a list of classes to apply the tuning. Of course, the interface would still be there, and we can have a default implementation that does a few automatic settings.

Another question. Do you expect that the 'auto' mode goes back and changes the table config with the settings (e.g. inverted indices etc.)? In other words, if we displayed the table config, will it show the automatically populated settings? If there is an interface and there can be multiple implementations, should it also not show which implemntation was used to arrive at the optimal config?

Good point ! It's possible that we have a chain of resolvers (similar to ingestion side transforms). We can consider this in the future. For now, I'm thinking of exactly one resolver (since we're still experimenting).

> Another question. Do you expect that the 'auto' mode goes back and changes the table config with the settings (e.g. inverted indices etc.)? In other words, if we displayed the table config, will it show the automatically populated settings? 

It's technically upto the implementation. But yes, I was thinking that the resolver will populate the recommended config and persist the changes. The next time you query the table config - you should be able to see the "resolved" config.

> If there is an interface and there can be multiple implementations, should it also not show which implemntation was used to arrive at the optimal config?

Currently I'm thinking of exactly one resolver in the controller config. With this in mind, probably not important to show this.

With the help from @npawar (thanks!), I got it to work. So to sum up,

1. Aggregation functions like `Avg`/`Sum`/`PercentileTDigest##` would all require `double` so need to convert the  groovy return to be `double`, which means all possible return values should be cast to `double` (eg using `column_name.toDouble()`) ;
2. I have a number literal, `0.0`, in the query which I assumed to make it double. Actually that became a `BigDecimal` and cause issue. So instead I used 0d and second exception is gone.
3. More exception could be found on server log, not broker log.

> Can we have a design doc on this before the PR review? Also what's the relationship between this and tiered storage #5553? cc @npawar

Thanks for bringing this up. Neha's design doc is here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Z4FLg3ezHpqvc6zhy0jR6Wi2OL8wLO_lRC6aLkskFgs/edit#

I remember raising a question of segments being in deep store, and proposing that we introduce a new helix state to indicate that. You can see the comments in the design doc. @noahprince22 something to consider as an option.

if you are running in docker, then you can config the dns resolvable host name in config file.

For docker, usually we can give each container a name, like `pinot-controller-0`, `pinot-broker-1`.
E.g. below will start a pinot controller in container named `pinot-controller-0`
```
docker run --rm -ti \
    --name pinot-controller-0 \
    --network=pinot-demo \
    --mount type=bind,source=/tmp/pinot-docker-conf,target=/tmp \
    -p 9000:9000 \
    apachepinot/pinot:latest StartController \
    -configFileName /tmp/controller.conf
```
Then for this setup we can configure the pinot controller host name registered in zk by adding below line into controller configure file.
```
controller.host=pinot-controller-0
```

Similarly, we can configure pinot server conf by adding below line:
```
pinot.server.netty.host=pinot-server-0
```
This `pinot-server-0` is the docker container name, so when we start the docker container, we need to specify the `--name `
e.g.
```
docker run --rm -ti \
    --name pinot-server-0 \
    --network=pinot-demo \
    --mount type=bind,source=/tmp/pinot-docker-conf,target=/tmp \
    apachepinot/pinot:latest StartServer \
    -zkAddress zookeeper:2181 -clusterName pinot-docker \
    -configFileName /tmp/server.conf
```

For Pinot broker, it's a bit tricky, the config to add right now is: 
`instanceId=Broker_${broker_host}_${broker_port}`
```
instanceId=Broker_pinot-broker-0_8099
```

Then you can goto `localhost:9000` to see that pinot instances names don't have ip address in them.
E.g.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1202120/98874702-9eba3b80-242f-11eb-8473-507fc2a8652b.png)

For a query with large `IN` clause, I was able to confirm that we reduced the mean query compilation time from 12ms to 8ms. Thanks for the patch.
@fx19880617 Thanks. But where can I find the config files, or do I need to make them myself?

> @fx19880617 Thanks. But where can I find the config files, or do I need to make them myself?

yes, you can follow this wiki(https://docs.pinot.apache.org/users/tutorials/use-s3-and-pinot-in-docker) to create a sample conf file, note that the wiki doesn't request a conf file for pinot-broker, but you need a one-line conf file to start pinot broker.

How does this play with `AutoAddInvertedIndexTool` we have?
Hi @icefury71 , config recommendation engine was recently implemented and that is aimed at auto-tuning as well. Did you take a look at that?
I don't think we should implement another auto-tuning engine. We should enhance the existing recommendation engine

> https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/master/pinot-tools/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/tools/AutoAddInvertedIndexTool.java
> and
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/blob/master/pinot-controller/src/main/java/org/apache/pinot/controller/util/AutoAddInvertedIndex.java



> How does this play with `AutoAddInvertedIndexTool` we have?

@mcvsubbu , The correct code to begin with for the newly implemented rule engine is RecommenderDriver.

This format won't be correctly handled, and the segment will be deleted by the retention manager mistakenly. So I don't think we need a migration path for it

I would suggest going with the easier approach (approach 1) and establish some baseline first. I would doubt that we can run into performance issue for the naive implementation as the partition based one works pretty good so far. The naive one should also work better if we have multiple pruners chained together. We can start the advanced one if we really observe performance issue from the naive one.

Added.
@Aka-shi ^^

> Seems like we are moving to `FixedBitSVForwardIndexReaderV2` by default. Just in case there's a production issue, the only option would be to rollback?

@mayankshriv Yes. I don't think it's worth adding a config to switch between readers. Per the perf, the new reader has way better performance in all scenarios.

> Could you confirm that this PR has behavior change only for large group-bys? For small/medium group-bys is it identical behavior? If not, could you call out the changes?

- For segment level, there is no change (even the PR doesn't introduce any change at segment level)
- For server and broker level, now the SQL also uses the 2 * 100k (configurable) as the trimThreshold. If any current use case is under 100k, there will not be any change.

Also, with this change, for SQL GROUP BY we can now use the configuration and fine-tune on a per use case basis to decrease the frequency of trimming (during upsert) just like it can be reduced to 0 for use cases with large group by.

> where is the logic to decide sparse vs sequential vs dense read

In `FixedBitSVForwardIndexReaderV2`, we use bulk read only for sequential doc ids. Per the benchmark, using bulk read for dense doc ids performs worse than unchecked read, so there is no difference for reading sparse and dense doc ids

This will allow for specifying a `@BeforeSuite` method to run `startZk(); startController()` once before all the suite test cases and `@AfterSuite` to run `stopController();stopZk();` after all the suite test cases.

Tagging @siddharthteotia @Jackie-Jiang for review.

Garbage collection during segment build has been a bigger problem for us than the segment build itself -- in the realtime path. In the offline path, where segments are built in hadoop/spark, we have not had issues with GC or performance.

Here is a prototype that I had done a while ago, using a columnar segment builder reduced GC significantly.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/issues/4036

Please use a similar technique and post GC results for some use cases where you hit performance problems (yes, unfortunately, the amount of garbage depends on the kind of columns you have -- I suspect performance also goes the same way).

In which scenario are you facing performance problems?
